sn7.1:1.2: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the Squirrel Sanctuary.
sn7.1:1.3: Now on that occasion the wife of a certain brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan, a brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī, had full confidence in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha.
sn7.1:1.4: Once, while the brahmin lady Dhanañjānī was bringing the brahmin his meal, she stumbled, whereupon she uttered three times this inspired utterance:
sn7.1:2.1: “Homage to the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One!
sn7.1:3.1: Homage to the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One!
sn7.1:4.1: Homage to the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One!”
sn7.1:5.1: When this was said, the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan said to her:
sn7.1:5.2: “For the slightest thing this wretched woman  spouts out praise of that shaveling ascetic!
sn7.1:5.3: Now, wretched woman, I am going to refute the doctrine of that teacher of yours. ʺ
sn7.1:5.4: “I do not see anyone, brahmin, in this world with its devas, Māra, and Brahmā, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and humans, who could refute the doctrine of the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
sn7.1:5.5: But go, brahmin. When you have gone, you will understand. ”
sn7.1:6.1: Then the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan, angry and displeased, approached the Blessed One and exchanged greetings with him.
sn7.1:6.2: When they had concluded their greetings and cordial talk, he sat down to one side,
sn7.1:6.3: and addressed the Blessed One in verse:
sn7.1:7.1: “Having slain what does one sleep soundly?
sn7.1:7.2: Having slain what does one not sorrow?
sn7.1:7.4: O Gotama, Whose killing you approve?”
sn7.1:8.1: [The Blessed One: ]  “Having slain anger, one sleeps soundly;
sn7.1:8.2: Having slain anger, one does not sorrow;
sn7.1:8.4: O brahmin, With its poisoned root and honeyed tip:
sn7.1:8.5: This is the killing the noble ones praise,
sn7.1:8.6: For having slain that, one does not sorrow. ”
sn7.1:9.1: When this was said, the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan said to the Blessed One:
sn7.1:9.3: The Dhamma has been made clear in many ways by Master Gotama, as though he were turning upright what had been turned upside down, revealing what was hidden, showing the way to one who was lost, or holding up a lamp in the dark for those with eyesight to see forms.
sn7.1:9.4: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, and to the Dhamma, and to the Bhikkhu Saṅgha.
sn7.1:9.5: May I receive the going forth under Master Gotama, may I receive the higher ordination?”
sn7.1:10.1: Then the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan received the going forth under the Blessed One, he received the higher ordination.
sn7.1:10.2: And soon, not long after his higher ordination, dwelling alone, withdrawn, diligent, ardent, and resolute, the Venerable Bhāradvāja, by realizing it for himself with direct knowledge, in this very life entered and dwelt in that unsurpassed goal of the holy life for the sake of which clansmen rightly go forth from the household life into homelessness.
sn7.1:10.3: He directly knew: “Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being. ”
sn7.1:10.4: And the Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the arahants.
